item.title: Australian election knife-edge
item.description:
Polling shows that today’s Australian election is a neck-and-neck contest between Labor and the centre-right Liberal Party. Even if Tony Abbott, the Liberal leader, doesn’t quite make it to become Australia’s next Prime Minister, this has been a striking turnabout for him and his party.

Some experts attribute this revival of Ozzie centre right fortunes to the modernising strategy Abbott and his tight-knit clique of advisers have followed since he took over as leader. “The break-through came when we made it clear we no longer believed in our traditional agenda” explained one Canberra insider yesterday.

“By ditching that old “right wing” agenda that used to focus on immigration, lower taxes and smaller government, we’ve stormed ahead with folk who’d never vote for us anyway”.

Instead, the closed clique of Canberra advisers decided to put tackling climate change at the centre of their agenda - and have seen a sharp increase in the Liberal's appeal as a consequence, think some.   

Arch modernisers have also put special focus on community engagement. “We’ve been sending teams of our activists out to Fiji to teach the kids ping pong. It’s win-win. They get to improve their forehand and back spin. In doing so, we get to show how we can make a difference in key suburban constituencies in Sydney and Melbourne, and maybe even in Broome, too. We hope” explained one. 

Faced with the most hopelessly divided, incompetent and badly led Labor party in a generation one key strategist explained “If we don’t win, we’ll focus on making the AV electoral system the issue. We will demand a referendum on adopting first-past-the-post, rather than face up to why it is we stuffed up”.

item.title: The internet gives us unprecedented freedom
item.description:
The Guardian’s Martin Kettle has an interesting article suggesting that the internet is having a profound cultural impact on the UK, leading to a “national mental disengagement with Europe”.  

With the whole planet just a few clicks away, “it is hard to recall a time” he laments” when the national .... mind was less informed about or engaged with Europe than it is today.  .... Being in Europe has never impinged less.”

Boo hoo. How tragic.

Perhaps the left is about to discover a broader truth; the internet makes it impossible for elites to try to shape the planet, and the people on it, according to their own preconceived notions of how the world should be. The dispersed, democratic medium that is the internet doesn’t produce a shiny new Euro-identity because that shiny new Euro-identity is the bogus product of a remote elite. And it’s not only top down Euro elitism that is threatened by the web. 

The internet frees us as citizens from politicians, as communities from the centralised state, as producers and consumers from mega corporations, and as people from our geography.   That's pretty catastrophic if you happen to be a Fabian supporter of centralised public service provision, who wants a regulated economy and see yourself as a Euro citizen. 

Bad news for Guardianistas. Good news for the rest of the planet.

item.title: Leon Brittan to advise on trade
item.description:
Leon Brittan has been appointed as a trade adviser to the government. Not that the UK government has any real say over UK trade policy. As an ex-Eurocrat, I’m sure Lord Brittan knows that already.   

But still, why not appoint as a trade adviser a man whose career saw him help lock UK trade ever more tightly into the sclerotic, high tax / high regulation Eurozone? It could be just the thing to stimulate trade with India and China.

The fact Lord L happens to have been explicitly hostile to the Tory cause in the run up to the last set of Euro elections even gives his elevation an uber moderniser, welcome-to-the-Big-Tent twist.   

Something tells me that his £500 per day review (according to the BBC) is unlikely conclude that we should boost our global trade by having less interference from Europe. Nor, if I was a gambling sort, would I put money on an ex-official ever proposing fewer officials, less regulation and lower taxation. Instead, I imagine any proposals will somehow offer the opposite - coordinated trade strategies, picking winners, and bigger export credit subsidies for big corporations ..... 

Perhaps Leon might be asked to lobby his former Eurocrat colleagues to ask if we might be allowed to have the sort of trade policy we need?  It is after all they, not anyone you voted for, who now decides.          

Enough about technocratic appointments. How are those Coalition proposals to make government more accountable to Parliament coming along?

item.title: AV referendum - it doesn't have to be this way
item.description:
Perhaps like me, you sense there’s something not right with our political system.  Yet you can't quite see how AV is the solution. 

Maybe, when the Coalition was first formed, you found yourself pleasantly surprised. So much so, that when Dave and Nick announced a referendum on electoral reform, you thought “why not?”

Over the summer, I’ve been looking hard to see how AV is the answer to anything. I still don't get it.

AV does nothing to solve the problem of “safe seat” party fiefdoms, which make so many MPs answer inward to party whips, rather than outward to local people.

Far from making our politicians more accountable, surely AV actually allows them to disregard large chunks of opinion? 

For a generation or so, we have been moving from a political system dominated by two-and-a-half parties, towards one with a spectrum of choice.  Voters want representation that is niche, distinctive, particular and local. Big political parties that only do generic brand politics, built on centrally controlled messages and parroted scripts, have lost market share as a consequence.

A cynic might see AV as the Westminster village’s response to its collective loss of market share.  With elections decided on second preferences, people's votes will eventually go to the established parties.  The established parties won't have quite the same need to go after people's votes.   The results will favour the generic and bland  – and maybe even the mediocrities, too. 

I remain puzzled as to why the Coalition is proposing a referendum on AV when neither the Tories nor the Lib Dems offered AV in their manifestos. Whatever thought process went into Coalition haggling, surely the point is that the people – not politicians - should have the final say over any change. So why not ensure that any referendum offers voters real choice, including the option of multi-member seats? Why not include Disraeli’s idea of three member boroughs? Irish-style STV?

The referendum on electoral reform must allow people to make a choice based on all the options – including multi-member seats - not merely the politicians’ preferences.

UPDATE:  One of my readers points out that STV in Ireland doesn't work, apparently.  It "creates a parliament of local interests ... focused on thier constituency".  The horror! ... when you can have a parliament of party interests in which MPs focus on gaining promotion from whips. 

And worse, there's "pork barrel" in Ireland, too, apparently.  Thank goodness schools, hospitals and defence contracts are never dished out in certain constituencies for political considerations under our electoral system ....

item.title: How to stop the cowboy clampers?
item.description:
Rogue car clampers are a real menace. Hardly a week goes by without a constituent complaining that they’ve been forced to pay £ hundreds for momentarily pulling onto a bit of pavement outside an empty shop. 

It’s also driving trade out of towns like Clacton. Pensioners stung with big bills, and confronted by foul-mouthed thugs, are hardly likely to shop in town again.

Something needs to be done. But what?

One idea would be to regulate those permitted to wheel clamp - and the fees they charge. But something tells me that putting an IPSA-type quango in charge is never an effective solution to anything.

Another proposal is a blanket ban on clamping vehicles on private land. It’s been suggested that this form part of the Freedom Bill.  A Freedom Bill that bans things is a novel idea, but not one that I’m sure is going to be 100% effective. I imagine that the thugs that extort money at present would be perfectly capable of doing so with a ticketing system that permitted them to demand payment, without actually having to use clamps. 

The heart of the problem is caused by the legal right of the cowboy clampers to demand payment, rather than the physical use of clamps. Ending this form of extortion means addressing the fact that the cowboy clampers are only able to extort money because the private landowner has signed a contract permitting them to do so.  

Unless one is proposing to ban the right of landowners to charge payment, why not allow those who have had vast sums taken off them (sometimes by extortion and threats) sue the landowner?

If we lived in a society where ordinary folk, rather than just the rich and the reckless, had access to justice in the courts, I imagine a private landowner that allowed cowboy clampers would soon find themselves of the receiving end of a writ. Unless a landowner had a specific and persistent problem with people parking on their land, they’d not want to sign a contract with a cowboy clamper without thinking through the potential liabilities very carefully – especially if threatening and aggressive behaviour were involved. After a couple of court cases, I imagine the problem would disappear.

Giving ordinary folk access to justice in the courts? Now that really is a radical idea for the Coalition to ponder. And it’d solve more than just the problem of unscrupulous car clampers ....

item.title: Government appoints MP adviser - shock
item.description:
In a surprise new move, ministers are expected to announce that a backbench MP will be made a government adviser.  The new “policy czar” will be brought in specifically to express opinions and make suggestions.

Whitehall sources confirm the role will be unpaid, and are keen to emphasize that ministers will not be under any obligation to take the MP’s advice. 

This latest appointment is seen as a major coup for the government.  It follows a string of appointments that have seen big names enticed into the Coalition “Big Tent”, such as retail magnate, Philip Green, BP boss, Lord Browne, as well as Will Hutton, Alan Milburn and David Halpern.

A government source said “Giving backbenchers a say in government is a new departure.  Normally Dave just sends them a Christmas card and stuff. Sometimes whips are required to imply that a job might be offered at some unspecified time in the future. But even when we’re left with no choice but to dish something out, it’s vital not to give them a role that involves deciding things"

“But the new politics means recognizing that our backbenchers aren’t just there to work in their constituencies and then vote the way we say.  Their views can count too.”

The new policy czar is expected to produce a major report that will look at the so-called “policy postcode lottery”. According to some think tankers, the policy postcode lottery means those with addresses in certain swanky parts of London are more likely to have a say compared to others. 

Some special advisers, however, are understood to oppose the move, and will want assurances before the new appointment can be confirmed.

“Obviously we need to reach out to former Blairites and celebrity people.  They are cool and having them on board helps show how much government has changed "said one. "But if we have to start having backbenchers involved, they must not be allowed to disrupt the smooth running of government, or say embarrassing things, or get on their high horse just because they got elected to the Commons”.

item.title: Matt d'Ancona's curious case for a graduate tax
item.description:
A curious piece in today's Telegraph has (the normally brilliant) Matthew d'Ancona claiming that a graduate tax is a Tory idea. 

His justification for saying so appears to be that before the 1992 General Election a Tory minister privately told him he favoured such a scheme.

Before the 1992 election, you could find all manner of Tory ministers privately telling you they favoured all sorts of daft things - from joining the Euro to putting VAT on fuel.  It was one of the reasons the centre right lost its way so disastrously in the years that followed.

A graduate tax is not a Conservative idea.  Far from helping the Big Society, it would do the opposite, drawing civic institutions and seats of learning ever more tightly under centralised state supervision.

Matthew is absolutely right that in order to maintain world class universities, we need to raise more money to fund them.  He is also correct in his assumption that those who benefit from a world class university education should contribute towards the costs. 

But that is an argument for freeing universities to set fees themselves. That way the extra money is collected by universities for courses provided by universities without having to have politicians, quangocrats and the architecture of Big Government get in the way. 

It is certainly not an argument for raising the tax burden on the most productive part of the work force in perpetuity , and making universities eternally dependent on state-hand outs .

item.title: Decentralising from the centre: the limits to Whitehall's localism
item.description:
Eric Pickles wants to ban local councils hiring lobbyists.  This follows his brilliant idea that councils should stop spending money on self-promotional newspapers. 

Three cheers to such sentiments.  However, I'm not sure that a blanket ban from Whitehall is the way to achieve it.

That town halls spend money on PR and self-promotion is symptomatic of a more fundamental problem; a lack of local accountability over tax and spend decisions.  Instead of further restricting how councils can spend money, we ought to be giving them much greater control over how they raise it. 

If a local council was largely self-financing, with most revenue raised from a local tax-base, local folk would not tolerate it if their money was spent wastefully - because they'd recognise it as their money.  

Unless there was a pretty compelling case for doing so, spending on PR and self-promotion would stop.  And because it was local folk on polling day, not remote officials, who decided what did or did not constitute wasteful spending, you might even see more people vote.    

If serious about localism, ministers need to address the fact that something like 93% of all UK tax revenue is collected centrally.  With so little raised locally, folk have less sense of ownership over what the town hall does with it.  

By imposing (yet another) restriction on what local authorities can do with public money, Whitehall is once again saying that they are better able to decide than local people.  Where’s the localism in that?   

In the early 1970s, a Conservative government came to office intending to decentralise control over the economy (Selsdon man). They soon discovered that you cannot easily decentralise from the centre. You cannot use the levers of executive power to hand power away.

(PS. For ideas on how in government one might hand power away, see the ironically titled book, The Plan.)

item.title: John Redwood's blog
item.description:
On quiet Fridays – or when charging around the constituency, as I am today - I often link to other blogs.

Today I link to another excellent blog entry by John Redwood, my highly respected colleague.  He makes some points that those who merely rehash the tried-but-failed King Charles Street orthodoxy about Britain and the EU would do well read.

Read it here .

item.title: Fox reforms at MoD
item.description:
Liam Fox is expected to announce major reform at the Ministry of Defence.  Good.

The armed forces themselves, as opposed to thousands of MoD pen-pushers, are likely to be able to make decisions over what kit to buy.  Excellent. 

Apparently, Lord Levene will head up a Defence Reform Unit.  Even better.

In the mid-1980s, Levene instigated reforms that increased competition for MoD contracts.  Since then, some of the progress has been undone by the way that the Defence Industrial Strategy has developed - and, some might suggest, too close a relationship between buyer (MoD) and seller (contractors).   

The contractors can be relied upon to argue against it, but Levene seems to understand how competition brings better value from a finite defence budget.   

If Levene is to bring real choice and competition to defence procurement, it is hard to see how the current protectionist system can survive. 

Good bye protectionist purchasing and hello off-the-shelf?  We shall soon see.
